doc.title: Canada Economics Comment: Real GDP Contracts By 1.6% in Q2; Q1 Revised Down to +2.0%
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/Canada Economics Comment Real GDP Contracts By 1.6 in Q2 Q1 Revised Down to 2.0Canada Economics Comment Real GDP Contrac_2025-08-29

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS
processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS

passages.text: BOTTOM LINE: Real GDP contracted \(6.6\%\) annualized in 2025 Q2 (vs. a downwardly revised \(+2.0\%\) in Q1), well below the \(- 0.7\%\) consensus forecast but only slightly below the \(- 1.5\%\) reading expected by the BoC in the latest MPR. The contraction largely reflected a \(27\%\) decline in real exports (broadly in line with the BoC's expectations) as frontloading in Q1 unwound and tariffs began to bite. The composition of today's GDP print was somewhat mixed, however, as real consumption growth \((+4.5\%)\) and residential investment \((+6.3\%)\) exceeded the BoC's expectations but nonresidential investment \((- 10.1\%)\) surprised notably to the downside. Government spending contributed 1.1pp to annualized GDP growth, while the volatile inventories category added 3.2pp. Real household net disposable income grew by \(0.8\%\) in Q1 (vs. \(+1.0\%\) in Q1) and the saving rate declined 1pp to \(5.0\%\) . Smoothing through the large swings in net trade, real GDP grew at an annualized pace of \(+0.2\%\) on average in H1, below the \(+0.4\%\) average pace expected in the July MPR and well below potential. As a result, we expect that the BoC will deem further easing necessary to close the output gap, and we maintain our call for a cut at the September meeting. We continue to see risks as skewed towards further easing.

GDP (qoq, ar) \(- 1.6\%\) for Q2, median forecast \(- 0.7\%\) , GS \(- 1.5\%\) , prior revised \(+2.0\%\) GDP (mom) \(- 0.1\%\) for June, median forecast \(+0.1\%\) , prior \(- 0.1\%\) GDP (yoy) \(+0.9\%\) for June, median forecast \(+1.3\%\) , prior \(+1.2\%\)

1. Real GDP contracted by \(1.6\%\) annualized in 2025 Q1, well below the \(-0.7\%\) consensus forecast but only slightly below the \(-1.5\%\) reading expected by the BoC in the latest MPR. The annualized growth rate for Q1 was revised down to \(+2.0\%\) from \(+2.2\%\) . However, final domestic demand grew by \(3.5\%\) annualized (vs. a downwardly revised \(-1.0\%\) in Q1), reflecting strength in household spending and residential investment which offset a sharp decline in real business nonresidential investment.

2. Real household final consumption expenditure increased by \(4.5\%\) annualized in Q2 (vs. \(+0.5\%\) in Q1, downwardly revised, and \(+1\%\) forecast in the July MPR) and contributed \(+2.4pp\) to real annualized GDP growth. Within household consumption,

real goods spending growth accelerated to \(+4.7\%\) (vs. \(+2.3\%\) ), reflecting a sharp rebound in spending on durable goods \((+10.4\%\) vs. \(- 5.9\%\) ) which was itself led by a \(24.6\%\) increase in real spending on new trucks, vans, and sport utility vehicles. This acceleration was offset by a slowdown in spending on semidurables \((+4.4\%\) vs. \(+13.0\%\) ) and nondurables \((+1.7\%\) vs. \(+4.2\%\) ). Real services spending growth also ticked up to \(+4.3\%\) (vs. \(- 0.8\%\) ). Real government consumption growth was \(+5.1\%\) in Q2 (vs. \(- 0.4\%\) ) and contributed 1.1pp to annualized real GDP growth.

3. Real business gross fixed capital formation declined by \(2.4\%\) annualized (vs. \(-4.9\%\) in Q1, downwardly revised, and \(-1\%\) forecast in the July MPR) and subtracted 0.4pp from annualized real GDP growth. Real business residential investment grew by \(6.3\%\) (vs. \(-12.2\%\) ). However, business nonresidential investment slowed to \(-10.1\%\) (vs. \(+1.1\%\) ), reflecting a steep decline in investment in equipment \((- 32.6\%\) vs. \(+10.1\%\) ) which was only partly offset by a rebound in investment in nonresidential structures \((+6.3\%\) vs. \(-3.9\%\) ). The contribution of the volatile inventory investment category to annualized real GDP growth was \(+3.2\) pp in Q2 (vs. 2.1pp).

4. Real exports of goods and services contracted by \(26.8\%\) annualized in Q2 (vs. \(+5.8\%\) in Q1 and \(-25\%\) forecast in the July MPR) and subtracted 9.8pp from annualized GDP growth. The release noted that exports of passenger cars and light trucks led this decline \((-68\%)\) , likely reflecting the unwind of frontloading in Q1 and lower demand due to tariffs. Real imports contracted by \(5.1\%\) annualized (vs. \(+3.6\%\) in Q1 and \(-10\%\) in the July MPR), also driven by passenger vehicles and light trucks \((-32\%)\) as well as travel services \((-30\%)\) amid Canadian boycotts of US products and travel, contributing 1.7pp to annualized growth.

5. Growth in compensation of employees slowed to a \(+0.7\%\) annualized pace in Q2 (vs. \(+3.1\%\) in Q1). Net property income grew by \(6.0\%\) (vs. \(-7.2\%\) ), reflecting an increase in property income received \((3.6\%)\) and modest growth in property income paid \((+0.3\%)\) . On net, household net disposable income grew by \(1.3\%\) in Q2 (vs. \(+3.9\%\) ). In real terms, household net disposable income grew by \(0.8\%\) (vs. \(+1.0\%\) ). The household saving rate declined to \(5.0\%\) from \(6.0\%\) in Q1.

6. Monthly real GDP declined by \(0.1\%\) in June, below consensus expectations for a \(0.7\%\) increase, reflecting a \(0.5\%\) decline in goods-producing industries which was only partly offset by a \(0.1\%\) increase for services-producing industries. Preliminary information indicates that real GDP grew by \(0.1\%\) in July.

7. The composition of today's GDP print was somewhat mixed. Net trade evolved broadly in line with the BoC's expectations as frontloading in Q1 unwound and tariffs began to bite. However, final domestic demand growth exceeded the BoC's expectations, albeit from a downwardly revised level in Q1. Strength was driven largely by stronger consumption growth (which in turn reflected a 1pp drop in the saving rate) and residential investment, but real business nonresidential investment surprised notably to the downside. Final domestic demand was also supported by a larger-than-expected increase in government spending. Smoothing through the large swings in net trade, real GDP grew at an annualized pace of \(+0.2\%\) on average in H1, below the \(+0.4\%\) average pace expected in the July MPR and well below potential. As a

result, we expect that the BoC will deem further easing necessary to close the output gap, and we maintain our call \(\text {C}\) cut at the September meeting. We continue to see risks as skewed towards further easing.

All research reports are disseminated and available to all clients simultaneously through electronic publication to our internal client websites. Not all research content is redistributed to our clients or available to third- party aggregators, nor is Goldman Sachs responsible for the redistribution of our research by third party aggregators.
